newsitem.title: USA: Tiffany slides a bit despite solid Q3.
newsitem.headline: Tiffany slides a bit despite solid Q3.

text.p: Shares of jeweller Tiffany & Co slid a bit Thursday despite solid third quarter profits and higher operating margins. Although the earnings topped Wall Street expectations by two cents a share, they may not have met "whisper" numbers, analysts said.

The stock fell 2 to 36-1/8 after Tiffany posted third quarter earnings per share of $0.26. First Call had put Wall Street consensus estimates at $0.24. Tiffany earned $0.19 last year. Sales rose to near $211 million for the quarter compared to $188 million last year.
"I think there has been a lot of over-reaction in the retail sector over the last week or so," said Kimberly Walin, a Furman Selz analyst who tracks New York-based Tiffany.
Tiffany shares rose 1-1/2 on Wednesday ahead of the release of the third quarter earnings.

"Perhaps people expected more, but the quality of the quarter was fabulous. People are also very spooked about Christmas for all retailers. Tiffany was one of the few that had a good Christmas last year, and we think trends will hold up very well for them," Walin said.
She raised 1996 earnings estimates $1.56 a share from $1.55 and bumped up 1997 profit estimates to $1.80 from $1.78.
Another analyst also speculated that investors may have been betting ahead of earnings that Tiffany would streak past the estimates and were disappointed by the results.

Tiffany said U.S. retail sales climbed 14 percent to $99.7 million in the quarter, and same-store sales in the United States rose 9.0 percent. For the year-to-date, U.S. same-store sales rose 11 percent.
Tiffany said its policy is not to comment on its stock price.
